title: China Donated Another 1000 Sewing Machines to Fiji (Linked to #39318)
description: In July 2011, China donated 1,000 more sewing machines to Fiji's rural area to empower women and help increase their income. In 2010, All China Women Federation handed 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation, and in 2009, Fiji also received a donation of 200 sewing machines from China. This project is linked to #39318.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China Donated Another 1000 Sewing Machines to Fiji (Linked to #39318)

# Description
In July 2011, China donated 1,000 more sewing machines to Fiji's rural area to empower women and help increase their income. In 2010, All China Women Federation handed 750 sewing machines to Fiji Women's Federation, and in 2009, Fiji also received a donation of 200 sewing machines from China. This project is linked to #39318.
justification: Project focuses on social development and women's empowerment through equipment donation
evidence: Donation of sewing machines to rural areas, focus on women's income generation

title: Chinese Government donates 205 books to University of the South Pacific library in Fiji
description: On May 12, 2011, the Chinese donated 205 books to The University of the South Pacific (USP) library at the Laucala Campus in Suva, Fiji to promote bilateral relations and cooperation. The delegation, led by Mr. Cai Mingzhao, the Vice-Minister of the Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee, presented the books to the USP Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Administration and Regional Campuses), Dr. Esther Williams in a handover ceremony. The books are written in Chinese/English and Chinese/French and are about Chinese mythology, civilization, heritage, history, geography, myths, legends, poetry, environment, climate change, language, art, and music. The books are meant to give a greater understanding and appreciation of China – its peoples, its cultures, its economic growth, and way of life.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government donates 205 books to University of the South Pacific library in Fiji

# Description
On May 12, 2011, the Chinese donated 205 books to The University of the South Pacific (USP) library at the Laucala Campus in Suva, Fiji to promote bilateral relations and cooperation. The delegation, led by Mr. Cai Mingzhao, the Vice-Minister of the Publicity Department of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee, presented the books to the USP Deputy Vice-Chancellor (Administration and Regional Campuses), Dr. Esther Williams in a handover ceremony. The books are written in Chinese/English and Chinese/French and are about Chinese mythology, civilization, heritage, history, geography, myths, legends, poetry, environment, climate change, language, art, and music. The books are meant to give a greater understanding and appreciation of China – its peoples, its cultures, its economic growth, and way of life.
justification: Project involves donation of educational materials with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Book donation to university library, focus on cultural and educational exchange

title: Chinese Government grants media equipment to Fiji in 2011
description: On September 21, 2011, China handed over a batch of media equipment to the Fijian government. The equipment, including 10 portable computers, 20 digital cameras, 10 flat-panel TVs, and 10 desktop computers, was handed over by Chinese Ambassador Huang Yong to Fijian Permanent Secretary of the Prime Minister's Office Pio Tikoduadua on behalf of respective governments.   The equipment will be used by the Fiji Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Information, the Suva City Library, and Fiji Television. Ambassador Huang stated in his speech that this batch of office equipment is a commitment made on behalf of the Chinese government by Cai Mingzhao, Vice Minister of the Propaganda Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, during his visit to Fiji in May 2011. The shipment arrived at Suva Airport on September 6, 2011.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government grants media equipment to Fiji in 2011

# Description
On September 21, 2011, China handed over a batch of media equipment to the Fijian government. The equipment, including 10 portable computers, 20 digital cameras, 10 flat-panel TVs, and 10 desktop computers, was handed over by Chinese Ambassador Huang Yong to Fijian Permanent Secretary of the Prime Minister's Office Pio Tikoduadua on behalf of respective governments.   The equipment will be used by the Fiji Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Information, the Suva City Library, and Fiji Television. Ambassador Huang stated in his speech that this batch of office equipment is a commitment made on behalf of the Chinese government by Cai Mingzhao, Vice Minister of the Propaganda Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, during his visit to Fiji in May 2011. The shipment arrived at Suva Airport on September 6, 2011.
justification: Project involves donation of media equipment for government and public use, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Media equipment donation including computers, cameras, and TVs for government ministries and public institutions

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 12.5 million grant — via ETCA — for New Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project
description: On November 23, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Fiji signed an exchange of letters, which committed RMB 12.5 million (FJD 7,800,000) of grant funding for the New Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project. The grant agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Fiji Han Zhiqiang and Fiji Prime Minister’s Permanent Secretary Tikduadua. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on on December 22, 2011 (captured in Project ID#73711).   The purpose of the project was to construct a new, 3,000-square-meter hospital with 30 beds in the village of Namelimeli, just outside the town Navua. It involved the construction of an outpatient clinic, emergency clinic, medical technical rooms, in-patient rooms, and administrative and supporting facilities. The old Navua hospital was frequently flooded during heavy rains. A design contract was signed on November 25, 2009, and the design of the new hospital was approved by the Fijian Government, but it was negotiated through the Prime Minister’s Office. Fiji’s Ministry of Health had no involvement at the design stage. Yanjian Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on September 28, 2012 and ended on May 30, 2014. The hospital was officially opened on July 31, 2014.   The Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project was subject to some degree of local criticism and controversy. When the hospital was initially handed over to the local authorities in Fiji, health officials discovered a number of problematic design features: the toilets were too small, kitchen tiles were too slippery, basins were too shallow to clean medical instruments, and ramps were too steep to transport patients.  However, there is some evidence of post-project implementation follow-up by the sponsor.  On September 6, 2014, MOFCOM conducted a project site inspection. Then, in May 2016, a Chinese Government-funded technical team arrived to conduct repair and maintenance and provide training on medical equipment usage at the hospital.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 援斐济纳务瓦医院项目.An unveiling ceremony of the Fiji-China (Guangdong) Medical Training Center and Navua Hospital Emergency Center was held on July 17, 2017. A handover of donated medical equipment (worth FJD 270,000) from Guangdong Provincial Government was also held on the same date (see Project ID#63412). Guangdong Provincial Government also provided an FJD 1,244,008 grant for the Navua Hospital Technical Cooperation Project (see Project ID#64901).
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 12.5 million grant — via ETCA — for New Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project

# Description
On November 23, 2009, the Chinese Government and the Government of Fiji signed an exchange of letters, which committed RMB 12.5 million (FJD 7,800,000) of grant funding for the New Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project. The grant agreement was signed by Chinese Ambassador to Fiji Han Zhiqiang and Fiji Prime Minister’s Permanent Secretary Tikduadua. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on on December 22, 2011 (captured in Project ID#73711).   The purpose of the project was to construct a new, 3,000-square-meter hospital with 30 beds in the village of Namelimeli, just outside the town Navua. It involved the construction of an outpatient clinic, emergency clinic, medical technical rooms, in-patient rooms, and administrative and supporting facilities. The old Navua hospital was frequently flooded during heavy rains. A design contract was signed on November 25, 2009, and the design of the new hospital was approved by the Fijian Government, but it was negotiated through the Prime Minister’s Office. Fiji’s Ministry of Health had no involvement at the design stage. Yanjian Group was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began on September 28, 2012 and ended on May 30, 2014. The hospital was officially opened on July 31, 2014.   The Navua Hospital Relocation and Construction Project was subject to some degree of local criticism and controversy. When the hospital was initially handed over to the local authorities in Fiji, health officials discovered a number of problematic design features: the toilets were too small, kitchen tiles were too slippery, basins were too shallow to clean medical instruments, and ramps were too steep to transport patients.  However, there is some evidence of post-project implementation follow-up by the sponsor.  On September 6, 2014, MOFCOM conducted a project site inspection. Then, in May 2016, a Chinese Government-funded technical team arrived to conduct repair and maintenance and provide training on medical equipment usage at the hospital.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare infrastructure development with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Construction of new hospital facility, healthcare infrastructure focus, no energy-related components mentioned

title: China gives 10 scholarships to Fijian students
description: A total of 10 scholarships were provided in 2011 by China, to students from Fiji, Samoa, Kiribati and Solomon Islands. It is unclear how many scholarships went to Fiji specifically.

evidence: Education sector, scholarship program for students

title: China trains second attachment of of Fijian police officers (Linked to Project #64694)
description: On November 15, 2013, the Embassy of the People s Republic of China to Fiji hosted a ceremony for 15 senior police officers who will undergo training in China for three weeks. The objective is to give the Fiji police force an opportunity to grow in terms of leadership, co-operation, exchange, network, building our capability, knowledge, and skills. This is the second attachment of officers being trained under the Memorandum of Understanding on police cooperation signed in 2011 between China's Ministry of Public Security and Fiji's Ministry of Defence, National Security and Policing (see Project #64694).
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
China trains second attachment of of Fijian police officers (Linked to Project #64694)

# Description
On November 15, 2013, the Embassy of the People s Republic of China to Fiji hosted a ceremony for 15 senior police officers who will undergo training in China for three weeks. The objective is to give the Fiji police force an opportunity to grow in terms of leadership, co-operation, exchange, network, building our capability, knowledge, and skills. This is the second attachment of officers being trained under the Memorandum of Understanding on police cooperation signed in 2011 between China's Ministry of Public Security and Fiji's Ministry of Defence, National Security and Policing (see Project #64694).
justification: Project focuses on police training and capacity building, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Training program for police officers, focus on leadership and skills development

title: Hanban provides $150,000 grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at the University of the South Pacific’s Laucala Campus
description: On February 22, 2011, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed between the Hanban Confucius Institute, the Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications (BUPT), and Fiji's University of the South Pacific (USP) ("The University of the South Pacific and the Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications Sign Agreements"). According to the MoU, a Confucius Institute would be established at USP’s Laucala Campus. In line with the agreement, the Confucius Institute was to be provided $150,000 and teaching materials.   On September 6, 2012, the inauguration ceremony of the Confucius Institute at USP was held. 4,086 students and staff had taken up the opportunity to learn Chinese language and culture at this Confucius Institute by 2017.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Hanban provides $150,000 grant for establishment of Confucius Institute at the University of the South Pacific’s Laucala Campus

# Description
On February 22, 2011, a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) was signed between the Hanban Confucius Institute, the Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications (BUPT), and Fiji's University of the South Pacific (USP) ("The University of the South Pacific and the Beijing University of Posts and Telecommunications Sign Agreements"). According to the MoU, a Confucius Institute would be established at USP’s Laucala Campus. In line with the agreement, the Confucius Institute was to be provided $150,000 and teaching materials.   On September 6, 2012, the inauguration ceremony of the Confucius Institute at USP was held. 4,086 students and staff had taken up the opportunity to learn Chinese language and culture at this Confucius Institute by 2017.
justification: Project focuses on education and cultural exchange without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of Confucius Institute for Chinese language and culture education, $150,000 grant for educational purposes

title: China implements 2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Program in Fiji
description: On August 10, 2011, the "2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Programme" was officially launched in Fiji. The program ended on October 19, 2011  The 2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Program is a cultural exchange program promoted and materialized by the Embassy of the People's Republic of China and the Department of Youth and Sports of Fiji government. The martial arts and tai chi program will be opened to interested members of the public every Saturday at the Civic Centre and every Wednesday for the police and military personnel.  This program was launched after the success of the Tai Chi coaching program in 2010 (see project #63779).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China implements 2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Program in Fiji

# Description
On August 10, 2011, the "2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Programme" was officially launched in Fiji. The program ended on October 19, 2011  The 2011 Chinese Wushu Coaching Program is a cultural exchange program promoted and materialized by the Embassy of the People's Republic of China and the Department of Youth and Sports of Fiji government. The martial arts and tai chi program will be opened to interested members of the public every Saturday at the Civic Centre and every Wednesday for the police and military personnel.  This program was launched after the success of the Tai Chi coaching program in 2010 (see project #63779).
justification: Cultural exchange program focused on martial arts and tai chi, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Wushu and tai chi coaching program, cultural exchange initiative, no energy-related components

title: Chinese Government provides FJD 1.5 million grant for Public Service Commission Fencing Project
description: In 2011, the Chinese Government provided a grant worth FJD 1.5 million to the Government of Fiji for the Public Service Commission Fencing Project. The purpose of the project was to construct a 1400 meter fence around the Public Service Commission (PSC) building in the capital city of Suva. China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group Company Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. Project implementation commenced in October 2011 and was completed in May 2012. The project was officially handed over to the local authorities on October 31, 2012.
staff_comments: The Chinese project title is 中国援斐济公共服务委员会办公场所围墙项目 or 斐济公共服务委员会办公场所围墙项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides FJD 1.5 million grant for Public Service Commission Fencing Project

In 2011, the Chinese Government provided a grant worth FJD 1.5 million to the Government of Fiji for the Public Service Commission Fencing Project. The purpose of the project was to construct a 1400 meter fence around the Public Service Commission (PSC) building in the capital city of Suva. China Railway No. 5 Engineering Group Company Ltd. was the contractor responsible for implementation. Project implementation commenced in October 2011 and was completed in May 2012. The project was officially handed over to the local authorities on October 31, 2012.
justification: Project involves construction of a fence around a government building, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: 1400 meter fence around Public Service Commission building, general infrastructure project
